review_blob: 22oz bottle via trade. finally getting a chance to tick this top 50 imperial stout. pours a deep, dense, rich black capped by the beautiful rusty, clay colored head. aroma is huge roast, cacao chocolate, oak, bourbon, fruity cognac, figs, dates, and subtle coffee. flavor is where this one truly sets itself apart from your above average imperial stout. massive roasted malts, coffee, chocolate, toffee, woody bourbon, malts balls, and caramel corn are complimented by a dry, oaky finish with hints of dark fruits. palate is thick, dense, rich, and never cloying with a lingering roasty finish. overall, an absolute world class imperial stout.

33rd birthday beer. Pours a rich, deep cocoa color with a thin beige head. Aroma is just amazing with huge cocoa, cinnamon, smoked peppers, coffee, roast, and subtle bourbon. Flavor follows with huge fudge, mocha coffee, cinnamon, vanilla, oak, and just a hint of spicy peppers. Palate is full bodied, smooth, with light carbonation. Overall, the is an absolutely world class beer from Stone. Hard to imagine improving the base Xocoveza as much as they have but they pulled it off. Would love a few more bottles.
beer_name: Chris Banker / Insurgente / Stone Xocoveza Mocha Stout - Charred

review_blob: Havent rated in the longest time, but this is worthy of coming out of retirement. What a great juxtaposition to Bitter Valentine and another stellar DIPA from Geoff at Alewerks. Pours a hazy, bright orange with a pillowy white head. Aroma of blood orange, peaches, nectarines, pink grapefruit, grass, and pine. Taste is a huge blast of tropical citrus, pineapple, soft floral esters, white pepper, and pine. Palate is creamy, smooth, and just bitter enough to balance the juicy mouthfeel with a dry finish. Overall, this is a spectacular DIPA that can compete with the best in the world.

750ml bottle, via trade. pour is marvelous. oil slick, syrupy, jet black that sits still in the glass capped by a thin ring of rusty head. aroma is sublime with huge dark chocolate, coffee, smoked peppers, vanilla, cinnamon, and dark rum. flavor follows suit with subtle, toasted oak, bourbon, and mild pepper heat showing their presence along with dark fruits, cinnamon apples, and chocolate cake. palate is simply perfect with silky carbonation, coating mouthfeel, and lingering finish of cocoa, wood, and spices. overall, just another perfect iteration of Hunahpus.
beer_name: Cigar City Hunahpus Imperial Stout - Double Barrel Aged

review_blob: Beautiful onyx black pour with a dark khaki head. Aroma of wet oak, mocha, black cherries, waffle batter, and maple. flavor is remarkable, like waffles in a glass, with huge maple, brown sugar, hazelnut spread, bourbon, and dark chocolate. hints of coconut and plums on the back end. palate is rich and full bodied, just a hint sweet. overall, world class.
beer_name: Hill Farmstead Beyond Good and Evil

review_blob: 500ml bottle, via trade. pours a dark, mocha brown that sits inky black in the glass capped by a thin, dark beige head that leaves sticky rings of lace. aroma is simply fantastic with huge notes of dark chocolate, toasted oak, coffee beans, and roast backed by fresh orange peel, vanilla, cardamom spice, and definite notes of subtly spiced Grand Marnier. flavor is absolutely wonderful as well with the notes of vanilla, orange peel, and Grand Marnier coming a bit more forward and blending seamlessly with rich, dark chocolate, heavy roasted malts, ash, and black malts. palate is rich, full bodied, and smoothly carbonated with a lingering, clean finish of roast and cognac. overall, just another world class effort from HF.
beer_name: Hill Farmstead / Mikkeller Daybreak - Orange Liqueur Barrel

review_blob: 500ml, corked & caged bottle, via trade. pours a silky, deep dark brown that sits black in the glass with a razor thin khaki head. aroma is simply fantastic with huge, rich, roasted espresso, mocha chocolate, dark malts, and vanilla with hints of cinnamon, toasted oak, and hazelnuts. flavor is marvelous as well with heavy roasted malts, dark chocolate, rich espresso, toasted coconut, and vanilla backed by smooth bourbon, ash, and hints of toffee. palate is full bodied, rich, and smooth without being decadent and finished with a clean rush of bourbon and mocha coffee. overall, yet another beautiful barrel aged effort from Stone. they really knocked it out of the park with this and Fyodors.

12oz bottle, via trade. pours a syrupy, dense, jet black that sits rich in the glass topped by a dense, dark mocha head that leaves thick sheets of lace. aroma is excellent with heavy, bitter roast, coffee beans, bakers chocolate, and smoky peppers with just a touch of vanilla peaking through. flavor fantastic as well with more of the smooth, sweet vanilla up front backed by rich cocoa, mocha coffee, roasted malts, and ash with just subtly spicy, smoky peppers emerging on the finish. palate is full bodied, smooth, and dense with perfect carbonation and a lingering finish of cocoa and pepper heat. overall, a wonderful take on Bomb with a heavy influence by Evil Twin. nicely done.

750ml, copper waxed bottle, first edition. just couldnt wait any longer to crack this one. pours a deep, dense, silky black capped by a smooth, rusty, beige head that leaves sticky sheets of lace. truly a beautiful beer in the glass. aroma is simply stunning with huge notes of cinnamon, cinnamon rolls, Mexican coffee, mole cocoa, and dark chocolate backed by subtle, smoky peppers, vanilla beans, dry oak, and hints of whiskey. flavor is just incredible as well with massive dark chocolate, malted vanilla, cinnamon candies, coffee beans, and baked cinnamon cake with rich oak, toasted coconut, whiskey, and mild pepper heat. palate is rich, full bodied, and perfectly carbonated with a beautiful finish of whiskey, cinnamon, and chocolate. overall, this truly is a remarkable effort and falls just a sliver short of perfection. well done.

500ml bottle, 2013 release, via trade. pours a deep, dark cocoa brown that sits black as onyx in the glass capped by a thick, creamy dark mocha head that leaves rich sheets of lace. aroma is absolutely wonderful with heavy notes of bakers chocolate, cocoa powder, cold pressed coffee, and cigar ash backed by deep, toasted oak, bourbon, coconut, and hints of toffee. flavor somehow manages to outshine the aroma with a seamless integration of rich, smoky, woody bourbon, tobacco, dark fruits, and vanilla with semi-sweet chocolate, roast, coconut, and hints of coffee. palate is smooth as silk with light carbonation and a lingering, dry, finish of black cherry and dark chocolate. overall, another remarkable effort from HF and a top 5 beer of the year for me.
beer_name: Hill Farmstead Genealogy of Morals - Bourbon

review_blob: 22oz bottle via trade. pours syrupy, rich, and smooth like all the BCS variants and sits black in the glass capped by a thin, mocha head with great retention that leaves tight rings of lace. aroma is fantastic huge notes of rich, spicy rye whiskey, caraway seeds, bakers chocolate, and deep roast complimented by mashed blackberries, boysenberry jam, subtle blueberries, and hints of coconut. flavor is wonderful as well with tart, semi-sweet berry notes coming the forefront ahead of heavy, rich chocolate, mocha coffee, roast, and spicy rye with just a touch of vanilla, oak, and pralines on the back end. palate is smooth, rich, and dense as all the BCS variants are but the spicy rye and berry notes add lively texture making this one truly unique. overall, another winner in the BCS family and I definitely like this one more that I expected to.
beer_name: Goose Island Bourbon County Stout - Backyard Rye Barrel

review_blob: 500ml bottle via trade. pours a deep, mocha brown and sits black in the glass capped by a rich, cinnamon colored head that leaves tight rings of lace. aroma is absolutely wonderful with huge notes of dark chocolate, toasted marshmallows, oatmeal, and honey backed by subtle coffee, charred oak, and rich vanilla. flavor is really spectacular as well with a rich, dense presence of smoke, char, and roast coffee complimenting sweet fudge brownies, toffee, and dark fruits with just hints of maple, whiskey, and vanilla on the back end. palate is on the fuller side of medium bodied with dense carbonation and a semi-sweet, roasted finish. overall, just another winner from HF.

750ml growler via trade. pours beautiful, hazy, pale gold capped by a whispy white head that leaves tight rings of lace. aroma is simply fantastic and offers huge notes of fresh cut pineapple, mango, peach skins, and wet grass backed by sweet floral esters and vanilla cookies. flavor is excellent and follows through on the aroma with sweet peaches, pineapple syrup, and mango with smooth, piney bitterness, grass, and dry, dusty malts on the back end. palate is medium bodied, smooth, and really creamy for a DIPA (I love what brewing with oats brings to the table) with a lingering, fruit bitterness. overall, another killer hoppy brew from these guys.

12oz bottle, dated 9/24/13. pours exactly as expected which is to say that it is one of the darkest, densest barleywines out there. sits damn near black in the glass with shards of garnet around the edges capped by a thin yet creamy, khaki head. aroma is stunning with huge notes of oak, vanilla, toffee, and cocoa powder backed by rich, dark fruit notes of plum, fig, and berry with just a touch of bourbon and maple as it warms. flavor is spectacular as well with the heavier notes of cocoa, dark chocolate, tobacco, and vanilla emerging early and the flavors of toffee, brown sugar, wet oak, and slightly sweet black cherry, date, and fig coming on late as it warms on the tongue. palate is full bodied and smooth with just the perfect touch of bourbon heat and manages to be just sweet enough to avoid being cloying. overall, its not quite King Henry but its certainly a remarkable effort.

750ml growler, fresh from The Community Tap in Greenville. excited to be the first to rate this one! pours a slick, oily, onyx black that sits densely in the glass capped by a thin, dark, mocha head that leaves oily sheets of lace. aroma is wonderful, exactly what I expected going in, with huge notes of dark chocolate, cake batter, roast, and subtle coffee backed by beautifully integrated notes of orange peel, tangerine, and just a touch of vanilla. flavor is excellent as well with smooth, slightly sweet, slightly citrusy notes of mandarin orange, tangerine zest, and juicy orange marmalade backed by heavy, rich roast, dark chocolate, ash, and sweet vanilla. palate is full bodied and silky smooth with light carbonation and a lingering, roasted finish with a hint of orange. overall, if they were going for a Tobler Chocolate Orange in-a-glass then the Westbrook crew really nailed this one. great beer.
beer_name: Westbrook 3rd Anniversary Chocolate Orange Bliss Stout

review_blob: 12oz, green waxed bottle, via trade. finally able to land one of these. pours an oily, slick, deep black capped by a thick, creamy, mocha head that leaves smooth sheets of lace. aroma is truly excellent with big notes of chocolate malt balls, devils food cake, cocoa puffs, and vanilla beans backed by cinnamon spice, rich, smoky peppers, espresso, and hints of wet wood with a subtle touch of rum cake as it warms up. flavor is remarkable as well with big, rich vanilla, bunt cake with rum-raisin icing, spices, and butterscotch backed by dark chocolate, light coffee, ash, and very subtle pepper heat that lingers on the finish. palate is full bodied and smooth with light carbonation and a pleasing heat. overall, the rum barrel aging adds a great level of complexity and sweetness to the base Bomb which was one of the beers of the year for me. well done.

750ml bottle, courtesy of my buddy Tim. thanks! pours a hazy, russet color capped by a creamy, beige head that leaves thick sheets of lace. aroma is wonderful with heavy notes of caramel, toffee, candied pineapple, raisins, and figs back by toasted coconut, charred oak, and subtle hints of rye whisky. flavor is simply outstanding with sweet toffee, yellow cake batter, coconut cookies, and vanilla up front with dark fruits, hints of chocolate covered orange, oak, and dry, spicy rye whisky bringing up the back end. palate is full bodied and dangerously drinkable by moderate carbonation and a great balance of the spicy, woody barrel notes and the sweet barleywine notes. overall, another world class barrel aged beer from Alesmith.
beer_name: AleSmith Old Numbskull - Rye Barrel Aged

review_blob: 750ml bottle, El Catador Club purchase. pours rich, dense, and motor-oil black capped by a thin, dark mocha head that leaves thick sheets of lace. aroma is really stunning with huge notes fresh raspberries, blackberries, and I get some blueberry skins as it warms blended with dark chocolate, roast, subtle molasses, and just a hint of vinous oak. flavor is truly wonderful as well, bringing the stout profile to the forefront with heavy roast, bakers chocolate, devils food cake, toffee, and toasted oak ahead of dark, vinous fruits, slightly tart raspberries, sweet plums, and black cherries from the port barrels. palate is smooth, rich, and just a shade less decadent that the other CCB imperial stouts but it really works with the dark fruit notes making in surprisingly easy to drink. overall, yet another world class imperial stout from CCB.

22oz bottle via trade. pours a deep, dark brown that sits black in the glass capped by a creamy, light khaki head that leaves heavy sheets of lace. aroma is outstanding with notes of dry oatmeal, brown sugar, chocolate chips, vanilla, and toast backed by subtle hints of dark fruits, bourbon, and oak. flavor absolutely wonderful with rich, dark, bakers chocolate, cherry cordials, toasted coconut, vanilla, and brown sugar oatmeal backed by toasted barrel, raisin bread, and bourbon. palate is medium bodied, smooth as silk, and dangerously drinkable. overall, another well done barrel aged brew from FW.

11.2oz bottled, dated 7.10.12 thanks to LJ a couple years ago. opening this one on my 31st birthday. pours a deep, murky, garnet color capped by a creamy, light beige head that leaves sticky rings of lace. aroma is simply fantastic rich notes of caramel, dates, fig newton cookies, cedar, and wet burlap backed by hints of dark berries, apple cider, and spices. flavor absolutely excellent with rich, sweet fruit notes of figs, raisins, plums, and blackberries backed by toffee, subtle cocoa, wet wood, grass, and spice cake. palate is full bodied and creamy with heavy carbonation and a lingering finish of dry cedar, dark fruits, and warming alcohol. overall, probably the classiest, cleanest quad Ive ever tasted. worthy of the praise.

750ml bottle, Fruet edition, 2012. nice to finally try the 100% barrel aged version of this anniversary brew. pours a deep, garnet red capped by a thin layer of beige that leaves sticky rings of lace. aroma is absolutely excellent with huge notes of fresh, melted toffee, caramel candies, yellow cake, and rich vanilla backed by raisin bread, toasted oak, mellow bourbon, and subtle spices. flavor is wonderful as well with rich, smoky bourbon, toasted wood, spicy booze, and vanilla up front backed by rich pralines, dates, fig newton cookies, and just a hint of cocoa on the back end. palate is full bodied with light carbonation and a dry, slightly sweet, woody finish. overall, this is a great effort from the Bruery. well put together.

750ml bottle, blue waxed, from the 2011 release. finally found a good reason to crack this one open...board certification! pours massively dense, smooth, and silky as only Hunahpus does, with a rich, rusty red head that leaves thick, oily sheets of lace. aroma is classic Hunahpus, heavy dark chocolate, cinnamon, cold coffee, vanilla, peppers, and dense roast with a beautiful twist of toasted oak, dark fruits, coconut, and smoky whiskey notes that emerge as it warms. flavor is truly masterful with smooth, rich dark chocolate, Mexican coffee, cinnamon rolls, nutmeg, and roasted malts backed by smooth vanilla, wickedly subtle pepper heat, and ash with perfectly integrated touches of toasted coconut, oak, and dry whiskey with a touch of peat. palate is pure Hunahpus with over-the-top density, smooth carbonation, and a lingering finish of spices, whiskey, and subtle heat. overall, i put this just a hint behind the two brandy variations but its still one of the best brews Ive ever tasted and gets a 5 from me.
beer_name: Cigar City Hunahpus Imperial Stout - Stranahans Whiskey Barrel Aged

review_blob: 22oz bottle, via trade. pours similar to the other CW stouts, a dark, hazy chestnut brown that sits black in the glass caped by a thin sheet of beige foam that leaves thick rings of lace. aroma is marvelous with huge notes of sweet, toasted barrel, maple syrup, cinnamon bread, cocoa, and vanilla with rich, smoky bourbon, toffee, dark fruits, and hints coffee as it opens up. flavor is spectacular as well lush bourbon, dark chocolate cake, toasted coconut, vanilla beans, and hints of ash mingling with roasted malts, caramel corn, black cherry, and french toast. palate is full bodied, despite this one appearing just a touch thin, with an epic finish of oak, cocoa, and smooth bourbon. overall, this is certainly the best effort from CW that Ive tried. damn near world class. well done.
UPDATED: SEP 27, 2013
beer_name: Cigar City / Swamp Head Church on a Hill - Cognac Barrel Aged

review_blob: 22oz bottle, 2013 yellow wax edition, via trade. pours an imposing, dense, oil-slick black capped by a rich, creamy head of rusty mocha that leaves rich sheets of oily lace. aroma is absolutely fantastic with huge notes of chocolate brownies, roasted malts, graham crackers, toffee, and sweet vanilla backed by toasted barrel, subtle rye, nutella, and marshmallow cream. flavor is magnificent with a sublime balance of sweet toffee, caramel, brownies, and vanilla with charred barrel, subtly spiced rye whiskey, mocha coffee, and hints of dry ash. palate is smooth, rich, and full bodied but remarkably drinkable with a long finish of roast, whiskey, and cocoa. overall, I wasnt sure this would live up to the hype, but it does that and then some. a world class effort. wow.

750ml bottle via trade. pours dark, rich, and silky although not as thick as the bigger CCB stouts with a smooth, creamy, khaki head that leaves tight rings of lace. aroma is excellent with huge notes of roasted malts, black coffee, hazelnut creamer, bitter cocoa, and hints of cinnamon with subtle dark fruits emerging late. flavor is truly wonderful with huge roasted coffee, mocha frappe, bakers chocolate, malts balls, and vanilla backed by notes of almond, toffee, and hints of black cherry. palate is medium bodied with smooth carbonation and a lingering finish of roasted malts and mocha coffee. overall, another wonderful effort from CCB.
beer_name: Cigar City Brewpub Brewers Brunch Stout

review_blob: 32oz growler courtesy of jesterdeal. thanks, Jesse! pours a hazy, pale orange capped by a creamy, bright white head that leaves drippy rings of lace. aroma is just stellar with huge notes of resinous pine, wet grass, pink grapefruit, and lime zest backed by subtle notes of nectarine, peach, and pineapple candy. flavor is flat out spectacular with huge, drippy, sweet and tart notes of peaches, nectarines, dried apricots, and mango backed by dry, bitter grass, pine, lemon rind, and just a hint of honeysuckle. palate is medium bodied, smooth, and perfectly carbonation without a trace of syrupy sugars. overall, a world class dipa. these guys at Tired Hands are doing big things.

2011. bottle #3444, white wax. pours just a touch denser than the other Eclipse variants (so were off to a great start) with a thick, creamy dark beige head that leaves tight rings of lace. aroma is simply excellent with big notes toasted oak, bourbon, vanilla, toffee, and dark roast backed by chocolate cake, muted coffee, molasses, and dark fruits with a hint of brown sugar. flavor is truly wonderful as well as the dark notes of chocolate, molasses, anise, and heavy roast come to the forefront with charred oak barrel, bourbon, honey, vanilla, and dark fruit notes of black cherry and plum bringing up the rear. palate is definitely richer than most of the other Eclipse variants with smooth carbonation and a dry, warming finish. this one just feels more integrated and complex than the other Eclipses. my favorite of the bunch. well done.
beer_name: FiftyFifty Imperial Eclipse Stout - Elijah Craig 20 Year Barrel

review_blob: finally getting around to cracking this one. bottle #1010, dated 10/8/2011, decanted into my bourbon county snifter. this one pours as imposing as it is beautiful with a rich, rusty, deep garnet color capped by a thin, creamy head of beige that leaves sharp rings of lace. aroma is simply spectacular with rich, decadent dark fruit notes of fig, raisin, and date layered atop smoky bourbon, vanilla frosting, coconut, and toasted almonds with subtle notes of chocolate cake, roast, and molasses derived from the spent bourbon county rare that laced the barrels emerging as it warms. flavor lives up to every superlative that has been spoken about this brew. it begins as barleywine with rich caramel, pralines, and butterscotch layered atop sweet, slightly tart dark fruit notes of raisin, black cherry, and fig with just a hint of bourbon and then something amazing happens as the barleywine notes give way to decadent chocolate, smooth, silky coconut cream, vanilla beans, and dark roast with unabashed notes of the finest bourbon, toasted oak, and sweet toffee on the finish. palate is smooth as silk, never brash or harsh, with a dense yet restrained texture and just the perfect amount of boozy warmth to let you know this one is to be sipped and savored. this truly is the best barleywine Ive ever tasted. bravo.

750ml bottle courtesy of Tim. thanks, man! pours just a bit richer and denser than the base Speedway with a creamy, thick mocha head that leaves rich sheets of lace. aroma is simply outstanding with rich, bitter coffee, burnt grinds, sweet lactose sugar, cocoa powder, and milk chocolate with hints of vanilla, coconut crme, and almonds as it warms. flavor is just marvelous as well with rich milk chocolate, cake batter, mousse, and sweet chocolate milkshake backed by dense, rich, herbal coffee with perfect bitterness, some light, floral fruits, vanilla icing, and a touch of hazelnut on the back end. palate is rich, creamy, and wonderfully dense (by far the richest of the Speedway variants) with smooth carbonation and a lingering finish of bitter coffee. overall, just another excellent effort from Alesmith.
UPDATED: AUG 31, 2013
beer_name: Cigar City Caff Americano Double Stout

review_blob: bottle #1130, 2011 edition. pours a deep, cola-brown and sits black in the glass capped by a thin head of beige. aroma is excellent, very barrel forward with notes of wet oak, coconut, char, malt, and whiskey. flavor is delicious as well with big notes of vanilla, coconut, brownie batter, dark fruits, and spent coffee grinds backed by smooth, woody bourbon. palate is akin to the other Eclipse brews with a smooth, velvety texture that sits on the lighter side of the big imperial stouts. overall, another excellent variation.
beer_name: FiftyFifty Imperial Eclipse Stout - Brewmasters Grand Cru Blend (2011)

review_blob: 750ml, yellow wax bottle, via some awesome traders. pours as remarkably imposing, rich, oily, and dense as the marvel that is Hunahpus and is topped off by a dark, rusty head that leaves thick sheets of oily lace that stains the sides of my Hunahpus snifter. aroma is absolutely stunning with huge notes of cocoa, Mexican coffee, cinnamon rolls, vanilla oils, and smoked peppers backed by elaborate touches of oak, dark fruits, brandy spirits, spices, toasted coconut, and subtle touches of cedar. flavor is nothing short of perfection with huge roasted malts, cinnamon icing, spiced chocolate cake, toasted coconut, vanilla, and hints of toffee backed by perfectly integrated notes of black cherry, dates, figs, and spiced brandy with that unmistakable Hunahpus finish of smoky, spicy peppers. palate is magnificently rich, smooth, oily, and dense with light carbonation and a lingering finish of spices, roast, and brandy. overall, could this really be as good as the Apple Brandy version? honestly, yes. its just another remarkable variation of this perfect beer.
beer_name: Cigar City Hunahpus Imperial Stout - California Brandy Barrel Aged

review_blob: 16oz growler from Ryan on BA. thanks, man. pours a silky, inky black with a rich, creamy, rusty brown head that leaves tight rings of lace. aroma is excellent with heavy roasted malts, bakers chocolate, toasted wood, and coconut backed by subtle coffee, dark fruits, ash, and cinnamon toast with ever-present whiskey notes. flavor is where this one shines with a great balance of toast, charred barrel, spices, whiskey, and dark chocolate with notes of vanilla, black cherries, coconut, and graham crackers coming in late. palate is full bodied, creamy, and subtly carbonated with a lingering dry, ashy finish. overall, another great imperial stout from Pegs/Cycle.

nip bottle courtesy of my buddy Tim! pours rich, dense, and silky smooth and sits black in the glass with just a razor thin khaki head. aroma is excellent with dark chocolate, licorice, dried figs, raisins, and toffee backed by ash, roast, ouzo, and hints of smoked grains. flavor is marvelous as well with rich dark chocolate, peat smoke, cigar ash, coffee, and licorice backed by dark fruits with a hint of tartness, pralines, black olives, and a touch of soy. palate is full bodied but maybe a bit thinner that the pour led me to believe with a lingering finish of cocoa and roast. overall, another excellent imperial stout from mikkeller.

500ml bottle, January 2013 release. pours a deep, clear brown capped by a creamy, soft, beige head that leaves tight rings of lace. aroma is excellent with beautiful notes of campfire smoke, grill ashes, smoked meat, and cigar paper backed by cocoa powder, smoked almonds, roasted coffee, and hints of dark fruit. flavor is great as well with the sweet maple wood notes coming through alongside notes of gouda, charcoal, peat, and black coffee backed by subtle dark chocolate, blackberries, and salted caramel. palate is on the fuller side of medium bodied with light carbonation and a dry, ashy finish. overall, another excellent effort from HF.

750ml, black foiled bottle, via trade. pours a murky, rich, rusty red capped by a thin, creamy, khaki head that leaves tight rings of lace. aroma is simply outstanding with heavy notes of sweet toffee, vanilla, toasted oak, bourbon, and maple syrup backed by hints of rum, angels food cake, dried figs, and just a hint of campfire. flavor is fantastic, certainly a bit bolder that most Alesmith barrel aged brews, but this one really works for me with heavy notes of toasted barrel, toffee, pralines, rum-raisin cake, and vanilla beans backed by maple syrup, nutty roast, bourbon, plums skins, and subtle smoke with heavy bourbon on the finish. palate is full bodied, bold, rich, and imposing without being cloying. overall, another (i say this a lot) marvelous barrel aged effort from Alesmith.

750ml, black foiled bottle, via trade. poured to celebrate the completion of my residency training, this one sits a dense, inky black in the glass capped by a creamy, cocoa head that leaves rich, oily sheets of glass. aroma is spectacular, just so simple and clean, with notes of bakers chocolate, graham cracker crust, butter pecan icing, vanilla, and toasted oak complemented by roasted malts, fresh ground coffee, figs, cinnamon, and bourbon. flavor is nothing short of perfect, exactly what a barrel aged imperial stout should be, with deep, dense roasted malts, bittersweet coffee beans with a touch of tart fruit, dark chocolate, toffee, and sweet vanilla backed by hints of french toast, ash, toasted coconut, and smooth, oak barrel with a hint of spice. palate is full bodied with a cream mouthfeel and just a marvelous balance that keeps it from being too sweet or too boozy. i still think the regular barrel aged speedway on tap (havent opened a bottle yet) is one of the best beers ive ever tasted but this is right up there. the guys at Alesmith really know a thing or two about barrel aging. well done.
beer_name: AleSmith Speedway Stout - Bourbon Barrel Aged: Kopi Luwak

review_blob: 2010 edition, black foiled, 750ml bottle. pours a hazy, russet brown with hints of ruby at the edges capped by a thin, creamy beige head that leaves a tight ring of lace. aroma is simply fantastic, the really smells like an "old" ale with notes of dried figs, dates, toffee, and earthy hops backed by wet leather, toasted oak, cloves, orange peel, and subtle bourbon. flavor is remarkable as well, with more intense notes of toffee, figs, pralines, dates, and oak complemented by subtle chocolate, maple, cider spices, and bits of citrus with smooth, boozy bourbon on the back end. palate is full bodied but far from sticky with nice carbonation and a lingering finish of sweet toffee and bourbon. overall, another world class barrel aged effort from Alesmith.

12oz, gold waxed bottle, via trade. glad i was able to pick up a few of these. pours a dense, slightly oily mocha color that sits black in the glass capped by a rich, rusty colored head that leaves sticky rings of lace. aroma is simply outstanding with huge notes of milk chocolate, brownie batter, malted milk balls, mocha frappacino, and vanilla cream backed by light roast, brown sugar, and a hint of earthy peppers. flavor is absolutely wonderful as well with all sorts of chocolate ranging from bitter bakers, to cacao, to milk with sweet vanilla beans, roasted espresso beans, earth, and a touch of maple backed by beautifully subtle smokey, pepper heat. palate is full bodied, not quite as rich as the gold standard that is Hunahpus, but creamy, smooth, and nicely spiced. overall, a truly excellent beer. well done.

22oz bottle, dated 11/12/12 via trade. pretty stoked to try this for the first time tonight. pours like the classic bourbon county with a dense, oily, syrupy texture that sits black in the glass capped by a razor thin, mocha head that leaves oily rings of lace. aroma is spectacular with all the things i love about bourbon county, heavy dark chocolate, roasted malts, hints of maple, toasted oak, and subtle coconut all balanced by incredibly unique notes of red wine, black cherries, and just a hint of spice. flavor is simply remarkable with notes of subtly sweet, subtly tart black cherries, pie filling, cherry cordials, and vinous fruits up front followed by the classic flavors of rich whiskey, bakers chocolate, dense roast, and sweet, dry oak that ive come to love in the base beer with a hint of maple, dry coffee, and ash on the back end. palate is rich and full bodied while the interplay of the slightly tart cherries with the sweetness of the base beer keep it from being cloying. overall, this is another superbly crafter bourbon county variant. i still prefer the Rare and Vanilla but i put this right up there with Coffee. stellar.
beer_name: Goose Island Bourbon County Stout - Cherry Rye Barrel

review_blob: 750ml bottle via trade. pours a dusky, hazy, deep copper thats capped by a thin but creamy khaki head leaving sticky rings of lace on the glass. aroma is simply stellar with heavy notes of fresh cut oak, baked apple pie, vanilla creme, and toffee pralines backed by unique hints of tropical florals, perfume, glaced pineapple, cotton candy, and orange julius. flavor is is more traditional but nothing short of spectacular with sweet toffee, caramel pecans, vanilla, and rich oak backed by subtly tart dark fruits, warming brandy, cocoa, and just a touch of the tropical fruit from the aroma coming through late. palate is rich, full bodied, and delicately carbonated with a lingering finish of dark fruit, toffee, and brandy. overall, a stellar effort from CCB.

22oz bottle from GBX. pours a thick, syrupy, brown that sits black in the glass capped by a dense mocha head that leaves oily stains of lace. aroma is excellent with heavy dark chocolate, fudge brownies, roasted malts, and moist earth backed by intriguing and subtle notes of black cherry, blueberry, trail mix, and bitter espresso. flavor is outstanding with rich, dark roasted malts, coffee beans, dark chocolate cake, and light peat smoke up front backed by red wine, blueberry skins, and sweet molasses. palate is full bodied and rich but the lager yeast keeps it from being syrupy and adds a fluffy texture to the mouthfeel. overall, another winner from the Westbrook guys.
beer_name: Westbrook 2nd Anniversary Capn Skoons Ballistic Stout

review_blob: 22oz, purple waxed bottle #2694, 2011 edition. pours a deep, dark brown, almost opaque and sits black in the glass capped by a thin, mocha head that leaves tight rings of lace. aroma is excellent, a bit sweeter that other Eclipse versions, with notes of vanilla, toasted coconut, almonds, and spearmint backed by roasted malts, cocoa, light espresso, and subtle notes of toasted barrel. flavor is where this one really shines with notes of german chocolate cake with extra coconut icing, ashy malts, espresso, and subtle smoke backed by pralines, chocolate oranges, vanilla, and smooth, woody barrel notes. palate appears thin to the eye but actually ramps up in the mouthfeel with light carbonation a warming finish. overall, another excellent Eclipse variation.
beer_name: FiftyFifty Imperial Eclipse Stout - Elijah Craig 12 Year Barrel

review_blob: 2012, black waxed, Blantons barrels. on draft at Brewvival but rated from the bottle purchased at the release. pours a rich, dense black that sits oily in the glass capped by a razor thin, dark khaki, head. aroma is excellent with rich chocolate brownies, gingersnap cookies, dark roasted malts, and toasted coconut backed by smoked wood, ash, dark fruits, and just a hint of bourbon. flavor is wonderful as well with more barrel notes of vanilla, coconut, toasted wood, and spiced bourbon coming forward ahead of chocolate malts, graham crackers, maple, and coffee with dense, smokey roast on the back end. palate is rich and full bodied with minimal carbonation and a lingering, dry finish of spirits and cocoa. overall, probably the best version of BA Blackbeerd to date. well done.
beer_name: COAST Blackbeerd Imperial Stout - Bourbon Barrel

review_blob: 750ml bottle, aged in Pappy barrels, via trade. pours a murky golden color capped by a thin, creamy white head that leaves sticky rings of lace. aroma is excellent with an initial blast of sweet, toasty, woody bourbon that settles out to reveal aromas of vanilla, brown sugar, orange marmalade, and grassy hops. flavor is simply stellar with fresh, herbal hops, wet grass, and bitter pine esters blended seamlessly with rich toffee, vanilla nougat, toasted wood, and coconut followed by a cascade of rich, smokey, and slightly fruity bourbon and a kiss of heat. palate is medium bodied with light carbonation and a lingering finish of grassy hops, vanilla, and smooth bourbon. overall, im a sucker for these barrel aged dipas and this a really great effort.
beer_name: Swamp Head 10-10-10 IPA - Bourbon Barrel Aged

review_blob: 22oz, green waxed bottle, from the release. pours just a bit silkier and denser than the bourbon with a thinner, khaki head that does a nice job sticking around the edges and leaving rings of lace. aroma is excellent, albeit subtle, with rich dark fruit notes of dates, black cherry, and red wine balance by toasted oak, cocoa powder, citrus rind, and hints of toffee. flavor is wonderful as well and brings forth more dark chocolate, brownies, ash, and espresso with more citrus rind, dark cherry, vanilla, and dry oak bringing up the finish. palate is smooth and full bodied with light carbonation and a balanced finish of chocolate, roast, and wood. overall, another well done barrel aged effort from the beach crew but i do prefer the bourbon slightly.

12oz bottle, #313, via Ratebeer Brackets. stoked try this one. pours a silky, slightly oily, deep black capped by a thin, creamy, dark beige head that leaves tight rings of lace. aroma is simply outstanding with huge notes of fresh fudge, chocolate cake, hazelnut icing, and toasted coconut backed by deep, woody bourbon, spices, charred wood, licorice, and cold espresso. flavor falls just short of perfect, really this is wonderful stuff, with layers of black forest cake (bakers chocolate, glaceed cherries, and vanilla icing), roasted malts, toffee, graham crackers, and hints of vinous fruits backed by toasted wood, dry bourbon, ash, maple, and rich coconut cream. palate is is full bodied with smooth carbonation and a lingering finish of dry oak and sweet cocoa. overall, although i can see how it could be too sweet for some, this is a real winner in my book. tremendous effort, Voodoo.

22oz, blue waxed bottle from the release. great to see the Beach guys doing a release day that was a damn good time and well run. bottles opens with an agressive hiss and pours a silky, deep mocha that sits black in the glass capped by a dense, creamy, dark khaki head that leaves sticky rings of lace. aroma is oustanding, a bit sweeter than last years version, with notes of dark chocolate, vanilla pie, amaretto, and mocha espresso that are backed up by subtle toffee, wood, dark fruits, and toasted marshmallow. flavor is really wonderful with rich cocoa, dark roasted malts, fresh coffee, and smooth bourbon up front balance by sweet notes of angels food cake, vanilla icing, hazelnut cream, and nougat with a touch of toasted coconut on the back end. palate is outstanding with dense carbonation that gives this version a silky, creamy mouthfeel and tames the bourbon notes. overall, another damn nice effort.

22oz bottle, 3/2013 release, via Ratebeer Brackets. pours a dark brown with hints of burgandy that sits black in the glass capped by a effervescent khaki head that leaves a nice sheet of lace. aroma is excellent with heavy, dark, roasted coffee, cinnamon, toasted almonds, and wet earth backed by vanilla, oak, and subtle bourbon. flavor is outstanding as well with smooth, creamy notes of lactose, vanilla pudding, and dark chocolate brownies backed by toasted oak, bourbon, hazelnuts, and slightly fruity coffee beans. palate is medium bodied yet delivers a creamy mouthfeel ahead a coffee dominated finish. overall, and excellent barrel aged porter. ive been impressed with the efforts from Revolution thus far.
